Knowledge Point: Verbs usually co-occur with at least one participant, namely a subject. Nonetheless, in certain discourse contexts, subject ellipsis occurs (cf. \sectref{sec:9.4.1}) and some SVCs allow for subjects to remain unexpressed (e.g. in certain types of motion-direction SVCs, cf. \sectref{sec:11.2.1}). Subjects subsume the actor roles of agent \REF{ex:key:1039} and experiencer\is{experiencer} \REF{ex:key:1040}:
Content 1: \gll \textbf{Dɛn} kéch=an, \textbf{dɛn} bít=an. | \gls 3PL catch=3SG.OBJ 3PL beat=3SG.OBJ | \glt ‘They caught him (and) they beat him.’
Content 2: \gll \textbf{E} lɛ́k dáns, \textbf{e} lɛ́k ambiente. | \gls 3SG.SBJ like dance 3SG.SBJ like live.it.up | \glt ‘She likes dancing, she likes to live it up.’

Knowledge Point: Next to that, subjects may instantiate the undergoer semantic roles of stimulus\is{stimulus}/body state in certain idiomatic expressions \REF{ex:key:1041}, theme\is{theme} in the intransitive alternation of locative verbs\is{locative verbs} \REF{ex:key:1042} and property items \REF{ex:key:1043}, and patient\is{patient} in the intransitive alternation of change-of-state verbs \REF{ex:key:1044}:
Content 1: \gll \textbf{Tɔ́sti} kéch mí. | \gls thirst catch 1SG.INDP | \glt ‘I’m thirsty.’
Content 2: Not found
Content 3: \gll \textbf{Di} \textbf{gɛ́l} strét. | \gls DEF girl be.straight | \glt ‘The girl is sincere.’
Content 4: \gll \textbf{A} kɔ́t. | \gls 1SG.SBJ cut | \glt ‘I’m cut [I have a gash].’

Knowledge Point: Objecthood is marked by word order\is{word order} alone with full nouns \REF{ex:key:1045} and by morphological case and word order with pronominal objects \REF{ex:key:1046}. Full nouns and pronominal objects may both appear in double-object constructions (cf. \sectref{sec:9.3.4}). The overt expression of objects is, in principle, optional although in practice prototypically transitive verbs are very likely to occur with an object. In \REF{ex:key:1047}, the object of nák ‘hit’ remains unexpressed, but it is coreferential with the suject e ‘\textsc{3sg.sbj}’ of the main clause:
Content 1: \gll Wé dɛn \textbf{sút} \textbf{di} \textbf{pɔ́sin} di pɔ́sin kin sék. | \gls SUB 3PL shoot DEF person DEF person HAB shake | \glt ‘When they’ve shot the person, the person shakes.’
Content 2: \gll Gó \textbf{púl}=\textbf{an} dé. | \gls go remove=3SG.OBJ BE.LOC | \glt ‘Go remove it there.’
Content 3: \gll Ɛf yu nó \textbf{nák}, e nó fít brók. | \gls if 2SG NEG hit 3SG.SBJ NEG can break | \glt ‘If you don’t hit (it), it can’t break.’

Knowledge Point: The goal\is{} and source of motion verbs\is{motion verbs} like gó ‘go’ and kɔmɔ́t ‘go/come out’ may also be expressed as objects, although prepositional phrases\is{prepositional phrases} are more common. Compare the goal object colegio ‘college’ in \REF{ex:key:1048}:
Content 1: \gll So wé yu \textbf{kɔmɔ́t} \textbf{colegio} (...) | \gls so SUB 2SG come.out college (...) | \glt ‘So when you came out of college (...)’

Knowledge Point: Transitive clauses involving movement verbs and their objects may also represent cases of idiomatic transitivity as in \REF{ex:key:1049}:
Content 1: \gll Di tín de \textbf{go} \textbf{mí} bad. | \gls DEF thing IPFV POT 1SG.INDP bad | \glt ‘The matter is going bad for me.’

Knowledge Point: The preposition fɔ ‘\textsc{prep}’ may introduce the stimulus NP of a small number of experiential verbs with affected agents. The corpus features five such verbs: bísin ‘bother, be busy (with)’, gládin ‘be glad (about)’, kɔ́stɔn ‘be used to’, lúkɔt ‘watch out (for)’, sém ‘be ashamed (about)’. Of these verbs, only lúkɔt is intransitive; the only non-subject participant this verb may appear with is a stimulus PP \REF{ex:key:1051}:
Content 1: \gll \textbf{Lúkɔt} \textbf{fɔ} tif-mán dɛn! | \gls look.out PREP steal.CPD-man PL | \glt ‘Watch out for thieves!’

Knowledge Point: Verbs other than the ones covered above invariably appear with stimulus objects rather than PPs. Compare lúk ‘look (at)’ in \REF{ex:key:1058}. Other verbs in this group are sí ‘see’, hía/yɛ́r ‘hear’ and listin ‘listen’:
Content 1: \gll A \textbf{lúk}=\textbf{an}. | \gls 1SG.SBJ look=3SG.OBJ | \glt ‘I looked at him.’

Knowledge Point: Prepositional phrases introduced by fɔ ‘\textsc{prep}’ also denote the semantic roles of purpose \REF{ex:key:1059} and cause \REF{ex:key:1060}, the latter in combination with a body state\is{body states}:
Content 1: \gll Mí gí dɛ́n diez mil \textbf{fɔ} \textbf{transporte}. | \gls 1SG.INDP give 3PL.INDP ten thousand PREP transport | \glt ‘I [EMP] gave them ten thousand (Francs) for transport.’
Content 2: \gll E dáy \textbf{fɔ} \textbf{tɔ́sti}. | \gls 3SG.SBJ die PREP thirsty | \glt ‘He died of thirst.’

Knowledge Point: Nevertheless, in the vast majority of cases, a cause of death due to a body state like hángri ‘hunger’, tɔ́sti ‘thirst’ \REF{ex:key:1061} or sɔfút ‘wound, injury’ \REF{ex:key:1062} is marked by wet ‘with’. Note however that the cause of a sickness is usually expressed as an associative object (cf. \sectref{sec:9.3.2}):\is{associative preposition}
Content 1: \gll E dáy \textbf{wet} \textbf{tɔ́sti}. | \gls 3SG.SBJ die with thirsty | \glt ‘He died of thirst.’
Content 2: \gll E dáy \textbf{wet} \textbf{sɔfút}. | \gls 3SG.SBJ die with wound | \glt ‘She died of her injury.’

Knowledge Point: The prepositions fɔséka ‘due to’ (and its less frequent variant foséko) \REF{ex:key:1063} and bikɔs ‘because, due to’ \REF{ex:key:1064} introduce prepositional phrases\is{prepositional phrases} with the semantic role of cause. However, bikɔs is seldom used as a preposition and far more common as a linker of cause clauses (cf. \sectref{sec:10.7.7}).
Content 1: \gll Na \textbf{fɔséka} \textbf{bɔ́n} \textbf{pikín}, e dáy. | \gls FOC due.to give.birth child 3SG.SBJ die | \glt ‘It’s due to childbirth (that) she died.’
Content 2: \gll Náw só pó gál dɛn dɔ́n bɔ́s in héd \textbf{bikɔs} \textbf{nátin}. | \gls now like.that poor girl 3PL PRF burst 3SG.POSS head due.to nothing | \glt ‘Now the poor girl, her head has been burst open because of nothing.’

Knowledge Point: The role of instrument is expressed through wet ‘with’ if instruments \REF{ex:key:1065}, materials \REF{ex:key:1066}, and functions \REF{ex:key:1067} are involved. Instruments and materials can also be expressed by argument-introducing SVCs involving ték ‘take’ (cf. \sectref{sec:9.1.4}):
Content 1: \gll Dɛn sút=an \textbf{wet} \textbf{gɔ́n} na in héd. | \gls 3PL shoot=3SG.OBJ with gun LOC 3SG.POSS head | \glt ‘He was shot in the head with a gun.’
Content 2: \gll Di hós bíl \textbf{wet} \textbf{plɛ́nk}. | \gls DEF house build with board | \glt ‘The house is built from boards.’
Content 3: \gll A wáka \textbf{wet} \textbf{fút}. | \gls 1SG.SBJ walk with foot | \glt ‘I walked by foot.’

Knowledge Point: Besides that, the preposition fɔ \is{associative preposition}is used for an instrument role in a more general sense of ‘by means of’ \REF{ex:key:1068}. Still, the functional overlap of wet and fɔ may lead to variation in the marking of certain expressions. Compare ‘walk by foot’ in \REF{ex:key:1067} above with \REF{ex:key:1069} below:
Content 1: \gll E de kwɛ́nch \textbf{fɔ} in sɛ́f. | \gls 3SG.SBJ IPFV die PREP 3SG.POSS self | \glt ‘It goes off by itself.’
Content 2: \gll A wáka \textbf{wet} \textbf{fút}. | \gls 1SG.SBJ walk with foot | \glt ‘I walked by foot.’
Content 3: \gll A wáka \textbf{fɔ} \textbf{fút} wet mi maleta. | \gls 1SG.SBJ walk PREP foot with 1SG.POSS suitcase | \glt ‘I walked by foot with my suitcase.’

Knowledge Point: The preposition wet ‘with’ introduces participants with a comitative role \REF{ex:key:1071}. A comitative role may also be expressed through an SVC involving fála ‘follow’ if the accompanee is human (cf. e.g. \ref{ex:key:1573}). Comitative wet ‘with’ may shade off into general circumstance \REF{ex:key:1072}:
Content 1: \gll Yu de ɛ́nta \textbf{wet} \textbf{sús}? | \gls 2SG IPFV enter with shoe | \glt ‘You’re coming in with shoes?’ [ge07fn 092]
Content 2: \gll Yɛ́s, Concha \textbf{fála} \textbf{Princess} \textbf{gó} viaje. | \gls yes NAME follow NAME go voyage | \glt ‘Yes, Concha went on the voyage together with Princess.’
Content 3: \gll Yu nó dán tín \textbf{wet} \textbf{yun-bɔ́y} nɔ́? | \gls 2SG know that thing with young.CPD-boy INTJ | \glt ‘You know that thing about young guys right?’

Knowledge Point: Negative comitative is occasionally expressed through a PP introduced by bitáwt ‘without’ (with the alternative pronunciation witáwt) \REF{ex:key:1073}. However, clausal alternatives are preferred to this rare preposition. One means of rendering ‘without’ is by employing a relative/adverbial clause construction introduced by wé ‘\textsc{sub}’ as in \REF{ex:key:1074}:
Content 1: \gll Dán mán de wáka \textbf{bitáwt} \textbf{sús} | \gls that man IPFV walk without shoe | \glt ‘That man is walking without shoes.’
Content 2: \gll A pás bɔkú tɛ́n \textbf{wé} a nó chɔ́p. | \gls 1SG.SBJ pass much time SUB 1SG.SBJ NEG eat | \glt ‘I spent a long time without eating.’

Knowledge Point: The use of a PP is only one of numerous means of expressing manner in Pichi \is{}(cf. e.g. \sectref{sec:7.7.2}), in which case the preposition wet ‘with’ usually serves this purpose \REF{ex:key:1075}. An equative or similative\is{similatives} participant is introduced by lɛk ‘like’ \REF{ex:key:1076}:
Content 1: \gll Yu nó de tɔ́k=an \textbf{wet} \textbf{páwa}. | \gls 2SG NEG IPFV talk=3SG.OBJ with power | \glt ‘You’re not saying it forcefully.’
Content 2: \gll (...) wi fít dé \textbf{lɛk} \textbf{kɔ́mpin}. | \gls (...) 1PL can BE.LOC like friend | \glt ‘(...) we can be (like) friends.’

Knowledge Point: Intransitive verbs may only appear with a subject\is{subjects} and may not take objects\is{objects}. Participants other than subjects appear in the guise of prepositional phrases\is{prepositional phrases}. For instance, the locomotion verbs fláy ‘fly’ and wáka ‘walk’ are intransitive. The use of theme\is{theme} \REF{ex:key:1080} or goal\is{goal} objects \REF{ex:key:1081} is rejected as ungrammatical:
Content 1: Not found
Content 2: Not found

Knowledge Point: In contrast to wáka ‘walk’ and fláy ‘fly’, other motion verbs\is{motion verbs} like gó ‘go’ can appear in transitive clauses, in which the goal is expressed as an object. This is particularly so when the goal object is a named place. Compare the object Lubá ‘(the town of) Luba’ in \REF{ex:key:1084}:
Content 1: \gll Dí miércoles a de \textbf{gó} \textbf{Lubá}. | \gls this wednesday 1SG.SBJ IPFV go PLACE | \glt ‘This Wednesday, I’m going to Luba.’

Knowledge Point: The transitive motion verb gó ‘go’ and the intransitive motion verb rɔ́n ‘run’ are also found with a meaning other than physical motion through space. Three such cases of idiomatic transitivity follow with gó ‘go’ in (\ref{ex:key:1085}–\ref{ex:key:1086}) and rɔ́n ‘run’ in \REF{ex:key:1087}:
Content 1: \gll Di tín de \textbf{gó} \textbf{mí} bád. | \gls DEF thing IPFV go 1SG.INDP bad | \glt ‘The matter is going bad for me.’
Content 2: \gll Dí fáyn klós de \textbf{gó} \textbf{yú}. | \gls this fine clothing IPFV go 2SG.INDP | \glt Lit. ‘These fine clothes go [fít] you.’
Content 3: \gll (...) e de \textbf{rɔ́n} \textbf{mí} kɔ́ntri tín dɛn. | \gls (...) 3SG.SBJ IPFV run 1SG.INDP country thing PL | \glt ‘(...) she was giving me a traditional treatment.’

Knowledge Point: The verb fɛ́t ‘fight’ cannot take an object either \REF{ex:key:1090}. A comitative participant needs to be expressed as a prepositional phrase \REF{ex:key:1091} or within a coordinate structure \REF{ex:key:1092}:
Content 1: Not found
Content 2: \gll Djunais de \textbf{fɛ́t} \textbf{wet} Boyé. | \gls NAME IPFV fight with NAME | \glt ‘Djunais is fighting with Boyé.’
Content 3: \gll Djunais \textbf{wet} Boyé dɛn de \textbf{fɛ́t}. | \gls NAME with NAME 3PL IPFV fight | \glt ‘Djunais and Boyé are fighting.’

Knowledge Point: The ground associated with the intransitive stative verb blánt ‘reside’ may only be expressed as a prepositional phrase (\ref{ex:key:1093}–\ref{ex:key:1094}):
Content 1: Not found
Content 2: \gll A \textbf{blánt} \textbf{na} Malábo. | \gls 1SG.SBJ reside LOC Malabo | \glt ‘I reside in Malabo.’

Knowledge Point: Intransitive property items include gúd ‘be good’ \REF{ex:key:1095} and bɛ́ta/bɛ́tɛ ‘be very good, better’ \REF{ex:key:1096}. With both property items, a valency-increasing causative construction is required in order to add a participant in addition to the subject \REF{ex:key:1097}{\fff}:
Content 1: Not found
Content 2: Not found
Content 3: \gll Gɔ́d go mék \textbf{e} \textbf{bɛ́tɛ}. | \gls God POT make 3SG.SBJ be.very.good | \glt ‘God will make it [things] good.’

Knowledge Point: Compare the intransitive verb gúd in the examples above to the transitive, causative \is{causative constructions}use of the labile verb fáyn ‘be fine’, which may be used transitively and intransitively with the corresponding changes in the semantic role of the subject. The undergoer (theme\is{theme}) subject of fáyn in \REF{ex:key:1098} becomes an actor (agent) subject\is{subjects} in \REF{ex:key:1099}. Even if this transitive, causativising use of fáyn is rather unusual, it is not ungrammatical:
Content 1: \gll Di húman \textbf{fáyn}. | \gls DEF woman be.fine | \glt ‘The woman is beautiful.’
Content 2: \gll Gɔ́d go \textbf{fáyn}=\textbf{an}. | \gls God POT fine=3SG.OBJ | \glt ‘God will make it [things] fine.’

Knowledge Point: Nevertheless, most if not all Pichi verbs may take cognate objects\is{cognate objects}, i.e. deverbal copies of themselves. In this way, even verbs unlikely to occur with objects in other contexts can be used transitively. Example \REF{ex:key:1100} involves the intransitive dynamic verb dáy ‘die’ followed by a cognate object:
Content 1: \gll Ey, dán káyn spɛ́tikul, a \textbf{dáy} \textbf{dáy}. | \gls INTJ that kind glasses 1SG.SBJ die die | \glt ‘Hey, that kind of glasses, (if I had it) I would die.’

Knowledge Point: In \REF{ex:key:1101}, the verb swɛla ‘swallow’ is followed by the patient\is{patient} object ín ‘\textsc{3sg.indp}’, and \REF{ex:key:1102} features the stimulus\is{stimulus} object mí ‘\textsc{1sg.indp}’, object to the body process verb láf ‘laugh’:
Content 1: \gll A \textbf{swɛla} \textbf{ín}, dɛn bin tɛ́l mí sé di tín go gró na mi bɛlɛ́. | \gls 1SG.SBJ swallow 3SG.INDP 3PL PST tell 1SG.INDP QUOT DEF thing POT grow LOC 1SG.POSS belly | \glt ‘I swallowed it, (and) I was told that the thing would grow in my stomach.’
Content 2: \gll Dásɔl e \textbf{láf} \textbf{mí}. | \gls only 3SG.SBJ laugh 1SG.INDP | \glt ‘He just laughed at me.’

Knowledge Point: There are no restrictions on the transitive use of body function verbs involving “effected objects{\fff}” \citep{Hopper1985}, objects that come into existence by the situation denoted by the verb. Compare swɛ́t ‘sweat’ featuring the effected object{\fff} wɔtá ‘water’ = ‘sweat’ \REF{ex:key:1103}. The same holds for experiential (or human propensity) verbs like jɛ́lɔs ‘envy, be jealous’, which may appear with a stimulus object \REF{ex:key:1104}:
Content 1: \gll A de \textbf{swɛ́t} \textbf{wɔtá}. | \gls 1SG.SBJ IPFV sweat water | \glt ‘I’m sweating.’
Content 2: \gll A de \textbf{jɛ́lɔs} \textbf{dán} \textbf{mán} só. | \gls 1SG.SBJ IPFV envy that man like.that | \glt ‘I just envy that man.’

Knowledge Point: Other verbs low on the transitivity scale behave no differently. For instance, typically stative situations denoted by colour-denoting property items may appear in transitive clauses with a patient object. Compare the labile verb blú ‘be blue, make blue’ in \REF{ex:key:1105}:
Content 1: \gll A wánt \textbf{blú} \textbf{dí} \textbf{motó} mék e chénch kɔ́la. | \gls 1SG.SBJ want make.blue this car SBJV 3SG.SBJ change colour | \glt ‘I want to (paint) this car blue for it to change (its) colour.’

Knowledge Point: In the same vein, neither a physical property like hɔ́t ‘be hot’ \REF{ex:key:1106}, nor a value concept like día ‘be expensive’ \REF{ex:key:1107} is barred from appearing in a transitive clause. Note the causativising effect of the transitive use of these inchoative-stative labile verbs in \REF{ex:key:1106} and \REF{ex:key:1107} below as well as in \REF{ex:key:1105} above:
Content 1: \gll \textbf{Hɔ́t} \textbf{di} \textbf{chɔ́p} bifó yu sɛ́n=an bifó. | \gls heat DEF food before 2SG send=3SG.OBJ before | \glt ‘Heat the food before you send it to the front [of the restaurant].’
Content 2: \gll Di gɔ́bna \textbf{dɔ́n} \textbf{día} \textbf{di} \textbf{petrol}. | \gls DEF government PRF make.expensive DEF petrol | \glt ‘The government has made petrol more expensive.’
Content 3: \gll \textbf{Hɔ́t} \textbf{di} \textbf{chɔ́p} bifó yu sɛ́n=an bifó. | \gls heat DEF food before 2SG send=3SG.OBJ before | \glt ‘Heat the food before you send it to the front [of the restaurant].’
Content 4: \gll Di gɔ́bna \textbf{dɔ́n} \textbf{día} \textbf{di} \textbf{petrol}. | \gls DEF government PRF make.expensive DEF petrol | \glt ‘The government has made petrol more expensive.’
Content 5: \gll A wánt \textbf{blú} \textbf{dí} \textbf{motó} mék e chénch kɔ́la. | \gls 1SG.SBJ want make.blue this car SBJV 3SG.SBJ change colour | \glt ‘I want to (paint) this car blue for it to change (its) colour.’

Knowledge Point: In the corpus, change-of-state verbs constitute the largest subclass of labile verbs. Some representative change-of-state verbs are provided in \REF{ex:key:1109}. With some verbs, the change of state of the subject is more likely to have been caused by (a) an external (usually animate and unmentioned) agent{\fff}, with others (b) by a cause internal to the subject (cf. \citealt{Croft1990}; \citealt{Haspelmath1993}; \citealt{LevinHovav1995}). This difference is reflected in the glosses given. Group (a) verbs are rendered with their dynamic meanings, group (b) with their stative meanings. The verbs are also loosely grouped along semantic criteria, such as ‘destruction’ (e.g. brók ‘break’, chakrá ‘destroy’), ‘material transformation’ (e.g. bɛ́n ‘bend’, bwɛ́l ‘boil’), ‘body state{\fff}s’ (e.g. bɛlfúl ‘be satiated’, táya ‘be tired’), and ‘natural states’ (e.g. rɔ́tin ‘be rotten’, sók ‘be wet’), ‘other human states’ (e.g. wɛ́r ‘wear’, máred ‘marry’):
Content 1: Not found

Knowledge Point: In the intransitive clause in \REF{ex:key:1110} below, the change-of-state verb chák ‘be drunk, get drunk’ takes an undergoer subject\is{subjects} (with the specific role of patient\is{patient}). In the transitive clause in \REF{ex:key:1111}, chák now takes an actor subject (with the specific role of agent) and an undergoer (patient) object. In the intransitive clause, the verb has a non-causative meaning, while the verb in the transitive clause has a causative meaning\is{causative constructions}.
Content 1: \gll Di wach-mán \textbf{chák}. | \gls DEF watch.CPD-man be.drunk | \glt ‘The guard is drunk.’
Content 2: \gll Dɛn \textbf{chák} \textbf{di} \textbf{wach-mán} fɔ́s fɔ mék dɛn fít gó tíf. | \gls 3PL get.drunk DEF watch.CPD-man first PREP SBJV 3PL can go steal | \glt ‘They got the guard drunk first in order for them to be able to steal.’

Knowledge Point: At the same time, the aspectual reading of the bare factative change of state verb is adjusted. When the verb is employed as a bare inchoative-stative verb in a basic intransitive clause, as in \REF{ex:key:1110} below, it normally receives a present tense\is{present tense} interpretation – the situation holds at reference time. In turn, the dynamic variant of chák receives a default past tense\is{past tense} interpretation in \REF{ex:key:1111}.
Content 1: \gll Di wach-mán \textbf{chák}. | \gls DEF watch.CPD-man be.drunk | \glt ‘The guard is drunk.’
Content 2: \gll Dɛn \textbf{chák} \textbf{di} \textbf{wach-mán} fɔ́s fɔ mék dɛn fít gó tíf. | \gls 3PL get.drunk DEF watch.CPD-man first PREP SBJV 3PL can go steal | \glt ‘They got the guard drunk first in order for them to be able to steal.’

Knowledge Point: When used intransitively with factative TMA, there is generally a stronger tendency for change-of-state verbs from group (b) to receive a stative interpretation, as in \REF{ex:key:1110} above. In contrast, many group (a) verbs are more likely to receive an inchoative interpretation focussing on the change-of-state, since most of these verbs feature an implicit agent or (natural) force\is{force}. When verbs with implicit agents appear in intransitive clauses, there is therefore a higher tendency for speakers to employ the perfect tense-aspect rather than factative TMA in order to indicate a change-of-state. The use of perfect marking via dɔ́n ‘\textsc{prf}’ focuses the end-state of the change of state.
Content 1: \gll Di wach-mán \textbf{chák}. | \gls DEF watch.CPD-man be.drunk | \glt ‘The guard is drunk.’

Knowledge Point: Compare fráy ‘fry’, an “agentive” group (a) verb in the intransitive and transitive clause, respectively. The combination of perfect marking and “agentive” verb renders a resultative meaning \is{resultative constructions}very close to passive\is{passive} voice in \REF{ex:key:1112}:
Content 1: \gll Di plantí \textbf{dɔ́n} \textbf{fráy}. | \gls DEF plantain PRF fry | \glt ‘The plantain has been fried.’

Knowledge Point: Two further semantic classes of labile verbs are locative verbs\is{locative verbs} and property items. These two subclasses alternate between inchoative-stative and dynamic uses. The two following examples involve the intransitive \REF{ex:key:1114} and transitive \REF{ex:key:1115} use of the locative verb lé ‘lie, lay’. The latter example also features the transitively used locative verb slíp ‘sleep, lie, lay’. A more extensive listing of locative verbs and a detailed treatment of their distribution is given in \sectref{sec:8.1.3}:
Content 1: \gll Di \textbf{kasára} \textbf{lé} míndul tú stík. | \gls DEF cassava lie middle two tree | \glt ‘The cassava is lying between two branches.’
Content 2: \gll E \textbf{lé} di \textbf{bɔ́tul} pantáp di tébul, e \textbf{slíp} \textbf{di} \textbf{bɔ́tul} pantáp di tébul. | \gls 3SG.SBJ lay DEF bottle top DEF table 3SG.SBJ lay DEF bottle top DEF table | \glt ‘He laid the bottle on the table, he brought the bottle into a horizontal position on the table.’

Knowledge Point: Property items of all other semantic types may be used in the same way as lɔ́n ‘(be) long’ (cf. \sectref{sec:4.1.2} for a listing of relevant semantic types). Compare the intransitive meaning of ‘be small’ of the dimension concept smɔ́l ‘(be) small’ in the intransitive clause in \REF{ex:key:1118} with the causative meaning ‘make small, shrink’ in the transitive clause in \REF{ex:key:1119}\is{causative constructions}. The imperfective marker de ‘\textsc{ipfv}’ specifies smɔ́l in \REF{ex:key:1119} just like any dynamic verb with simultaneous taxis:
Content 1: \gll Dí klós \textbf{smɔ́l}. | \gls DEF clothing be.small | \glt ‘This (piece of) clothing is small.’
Content 2: \gll Sɔn klós dɛn dé, hɔt-wɔtá \textbf{de} \textbf{smɔ́l}=\textbf{an}. | \gls some clothing PL BE.LOC hot.CPD-water IPFV make.small=3SG.OBJ | \glt ‘There are some clothes, hot water shrinks them.’
Content 3: \gll Sɔn klós dɛn dé, hɔt-wɔtá \textbf{de} \textbf{smɔ́l}=\textbf{an}. | \gls some clothing PL BE.LOC hot.CPD-water IPFV make.small=3SG.OBJ | \glt ‘There are some clothes, hot water shrinks them.’

Knowledge Point: Now consider the transitive use of fáyn in the following two sentences. Note that a transitive use may also lead to an idiosyncratic meaning of fáyn. Knowledge Point: Sentence \REF{ex:key:1133} illustrates the expletive use of the locative-existential copula\is{copula!locative-existential} dé in the factive clause e dé sé ‘it’s that’. The second occurrence of dé also shows that when the copula dé functions as the predicate of an existential clause, the existing entity (i.e. sɔn wích ‘(some) witches’) must be expressed as the subject of the clause. Hence, existential clauses featuring dé have no expletive subjects:
Content 1: \gll \textbf{E} \textbf{dé} \textbf{sé}, yu sabí sé yá só \textbf{sɔn} \textbf{wích} \textbf{dé} nɔ́. | \gls 3SG.SBJ BE.LOC QUOT 2SG know QUOT here like.that some sorcerer BE.LOC INTJ | \glt ‘It is that, you know that here there are sorcerers, right.’

Knowledge Point: There is no difference in meaning between the use of dé \textsc{‘be.loc’} and the identity copulas bí and na/nóto in factive clauses like the following two. However, contrary to other elements with expletive subjects, na\textit{\textup{/}}nóto may never occur with the dummy\is{dummy nouns} subject e ‘\textsc{3sg.sbj}’ in factive clauses, nor be preceded by an emphatic pronoun as is the case in equative clauses\is{equative clauses} (cf. \sectref{sec:7.6.1}). This is so because the focus markers/identity copulas na\textit{\textup{/}}nóto incorporate \textsc{3sg} reference (cf. \sectref{sec:7.6.1}). The identity copula bí may also appear with an expletive subject in factive clauses in the place of dé ‘\textsc{be.loc}’ \REF{ex:key:1134}:
Content 1: \gll \textbf{E} \textbf{fít} \textbf{bí} sé na paludismo. | \gls 3SG.SBJ can BE QUOT FOC malaria | \glt ‘It could be that it’s malaria.’

Knowledge Point: In these functions, bí and dé are also used as introductory formulas of narratives with the meaning ‘it came to pass that’ \REF{ex:key:1135}:
Content 1: \gll \textbf{E} \textbf{kán} \textbf{bí} \textbf{sé} mi abuela, wé a bin smɔ́l, e gó ríba (...) | \gls 3SG.SBJ PFV BE QUOT 1SG.POSS grandmother SUB 1SG.SBJ PST BE.small 3SG.SBJ go river (...) | \glt ‘It came to pass that my grandmother, when I was small, she went to the river (...)’

Knowledge Point: The two verbs falta ‘lack’ (< Sp. faltar ‘lack’) and sigue ‘continue, follow’ (< Sp. seguir ‘continue, follow’) are established loans of \ili{Spanish} origin which have been borrowed\is{borrowing} together with their selectional properties. Examples \REF{ex:key:1148} and \REF{ex:key:1149} therefore feature the expletive pronoun e \textsc{‘3sg.sbj’}:

Content 2: \gll Porque \textbf{e} \textbf{de} \textbf{sigue} wán bád smɛ́l. | \gls because 3SG.SBJ IPFV follow one bad smell | \glt ‘Because there follows a bad smell.’

Content 1: Not found
Content 2: \gll E sé \textbf{e} nó fít \textbf{falta}. | \gls 3SG.SBJ QUOT 3SG.SBJ NEG can lack | \glt ‘She said she can’t be absent.’
Content 3: \gll Porque \textbf{e} \textbf{de} \textbf{sigue} wán bád smɛ́l. | \gls because 3SG.SBJ IPFV follow one bad smell | \glt ‘Because there follows a bad smell.’

Knowledge Point: At this point, a word is in order on the raising properties of expletive verbs. In \REF{ex:key:1152} below, the \textsc{3sg.sbj} pronoun e anaphorically refers to dɛn yón ‘theirs’, so the object of the complement clause beginning with the non-finite complementiser fɔ ‘\textsc{prep}’ has been raised into subject position in the main clause. For other speakers, however, raising is not accepted with evaluative verbs \REF{ex:key:1153}:
Content 1: \gll (...) bɔt \textbf{dɛn} \textbf{yón} fáyn, \textbf{e} fáyn fɔ sí. | \gls (...) but 3PL own fine 3SG.SBJ fine PREP see | \glt ‘(...) but theirs is beautiful, it [the wedding ceremony] is beautiful to see.’

Knowledge Point: The verb fíba ‘resemble’ takes full complement clauses\is{complement clauses} introduced by the complementiser sé \REF{ex:key:1154}. Neither reduced fɔ{}-complement clauses nor SVCs are accepted in clause linkage. Hence, an SVC like \REF{ex:key:1155} is ungrammatical:
Content 1: \gll \textbf{E} \textbf{fíba} \textbf{sé} Boyé gɛ́t mɔní. | \gls 3SG.SBJ seem QUOT NAME get money | \glt ‘It seems that Boyé has money.’
Content 2: Not found

Knowledge Point: However, the subject of the complement clause may be raised into subject position of the main clause without any structural change. The result is an idiosyncratic structure, in which the coreferential subjects of the main and subordinate clauses are both overtly expressed \REF{ex:key:1156}:
Content 1: \gll Boyé \textbf{fíba} \textbf{sé} \textbf{e} gɛ́t mɔní. | \gls NAME seem QUOT 3SG.SBJ get money | \glt ‘Boyé seems to have money.’ [Lit. ‘Boyé seems that he has money.’]

Knowledge Point: The verb gɛ́t is an inchoative-stative transitive verb, which occurs with a stative \REF{ex:key:1157}, and at other times, an inchoative reading \REF{ex:key:1158}. The verb also has various functions as an existential and modal verb and expresses possession{\fff} (cf. e.g. \ref{ex:key:1159} below).
Content 1: \gll Dɛn \textbf{gɛ́t} wók náw ó. | \gls 3PL get work now SP | \glt ‘They actually have work now.’
Content 2: \gll E \textbf{gɛ́t} ɔ́da húman ‘chíp’ bɔkú problema, (...) | \gls 3SG.SBJ get other woman [SKT] much problem (...) | \glt ‘He got (himself) another woman, many problems, (...)’
Content 3: \gll Smɔ́l gál, ɛf e nó \textbf{gɛ́t} \textbf{wán} \textbf{bɔ́y}, e nó \textbf{gɛ́t} \textbf{mán}, pero di húman, di bíg wán dɛn sɛ́f. | \gls small girl if 3SG.SBJ NEG get one boy 3SG.SBJ NEG get man but DEF woman DEF big one PL EMP | \glt ‘As for young girls, if they don’t have a boy-friend, if they don’t have a man [they feel worthless], but even women, the grown ones themselves.’

Knowledge Point: Ordinary objects of gɛ́t may occur bare or be preceded by determiners depending on pragmatic circumstance. In \REF{ex:key:1159}, the non-specific noun bɔ́y ‘boy’ is preceded by the indefinite determiner wán. In contrast, non-specific objects of light verbs have a strong tendency to occur devoid of any definiteness{\fff} marking. In \REF{ex:key:1159}, the noun mán ‘man’ of the light verb construction gɛ́t mán ‘have a man/husband’ remains bare:
Content 1: \gll Smɔ́l gál, ɛf e nó \textbf{gɛ́t} \textbf{wán} \textbf{bɔ́y}, e nó \textbf{gɛ́t} \textbf{mán}, pero di húman, di bíg wán dɛn sɛ́f. | \gls small girl if 3SG.SBJ NEG get one boy 3SG.SBJ NEG get man but DEF woman DEF big one PL EMP | \glt ‘As for young girls, if they don’t have a boy-friend, if they don’t have a man [they feel worthless], but even women, the grown ones themselves.’
Content 2: \gll Smɔ́l gál, ɛf e nó \textbf{gɛ́t} \textbf{wán} \textbf{bɔ́y}, e nó \textbf{gɛ́t} \textbf{mán}, pero di húman, di bíg wán dɛn sɛ́f. | \gls small girl if 3SG.SBJ NEG get one boy 3SG.SBJ NEG get man but DEF woman DEF big one PL EMP | \glt ‘As for young girls, if they don’t have a boy-friend, if they don’t have a man [they feel worthless], but even women, the grown ones themselves.’

Knowledge Point: Objects of gɛ́t may be pluralised with a post-posed dɛn \REF{ex:key:1160} and may occur with prenominal modifiers like bɔkú ‘much’ or the \textsc{1sg} possessive pronoun mi \REF{ex:key:1160}. Knowledge Point: In Pichi, syntactic objects can denote various less central semantic roles which may alternatively be expressed through prepositional phrases\is{prepositional phrases}. Accordingly, associative objects appear to the right of patient\is{patient} objects in double-object constructions (cf. \sectref{sec:9.3.4}), in a position usually reserved for adverbial adjuncts\is{adjuncts}. An associative object is an instantiation of some entity typically associated with the situation denoted by the verb. Associative objects in Pichi are reminiscent of inherent object constructions as found in the Kwa languages of West Africa (see \citealt{Essegbey1999} for Ewe). Contrary to inherent objects, however, associative objects are not obligatory and may remain unexpressed at all times. Equally, associative objects usually only occur with specific verbs (cf. e.g. \ref{ex:key:1179}). The verb-object collocations described in this section therefore appear to involve specialisation or lexicalisation. The use of associative objects can therefore only serve as a productive means of increasing verb valency with the verbs listed in \tabref{tab:key:9.9}.
Content 1: Not found

Knowledge Point: Associative objects are assigned a content role by the labile change-of-state verbs fúlɔp ‘fill up’ \REF{ex:key:1173} and pák ‘pack, fill up’ \REF{ex:key:1174}:

Content 2: \gll E \textbf{fúlɔp} di glás \textbf{wet} \textbf{watá}. | \gls 3SG.SBJ fill DEF glass with water | \glt ‘He filled the glass with water.’
