Content 3: \gll Dɛn de \textbf{kapú} \textbf{fɔ} di \textbf{hós}. | \gls 3PL IPFV fight.over PREP DEF house | \glt ‘They’re fighting over the house.’

Knowledge Point: The source\is{} of the motion verb\is{motion verbs} fɔdɔ́n ‘fall’ may be realised as an associative object \REF{ex:key:1183}. Alternatively, the source may be indicated via the preposition frɔn ‘from’ when it marks the ground \REF{ex:key:1184}. Note the possibility of additionally using the “at rest” locative noun\is{locative nouns} ɔ́p ‘up(perside)’ to mark the ground in \REF{ex:key:1184}:
Content 1: \gll Di pikín \textbf{fɔdɔ́n} \textbf{di} \textbf{stík}. | \gls DEF child fall DEF tree | \glt ‘The child fell from the tree.’
Content 2: \gll Di pikín \textbf{fɔdɔ́n} \textbf{frɔn} \textbf{ɔ́p} \textbf{di} \textbf{stík}, frɔn di stík. | \gls DEF child fall from up DEF tree from DEF tree | \glt ‘The child fell from (up on) the tree, from the tree.’
Content 3: \gll Di pikín \textbf{fɔdɔ́n} \textbf{frɔn} \textbf{ɔ́p} \textbf{di} \textbf{stík}, frɔn di stík. | \gls DEF child fall from up DEF tree from DEF tree | \glt ‘The child fell from (up on) the tree, from the tree.’

Knowledge Point: The semantic role of the objects of smɛ́l ‘smell’ can only be disambiguated by context. In \REF{ex:key:1185} the associative object chɔ́p ‘food’ denotes the source of the sensation, in \REF{ex:key:1186}, chɔ́p denotes the stimulus{\fff}:
Content 1: \gll E de kúk, áfta e de \textbf{smɛ́l} \textbf{chɔ́p}. | \gls 3SG.SBJ IPFV cook then 3SG.SBJ IPFV smell food | \glt ‘He’s cooking, afterwards he’ll smell of food.’
Content 2: \gll Yu de \textbf{smɛ́l} \textbf{chɔ́p}, dɛn de fráy ɛ́ks dé. | \gls 2SG IPFV smell food 3PL IPFV fry egg there | \glt ‘You smell food, they’re frying eggs there.’

Knowledge Point: Another instance of an associative object with the semantic role of cause is mɔní ‘money’, the object of kráy ‘cry’ in \REF{ex:key:1190}:
Content 1: \gll (...) dán papá de \textbf{kráy} in \textbf{mɔní}. | \gls (...) that father IPFV cry 3SG.POSS money. | \glt ‘(...) that elderly man was crying over his (lost) money.’

Knowledge Point: An associative object may be fronted for emphasis \REF{ex:key:1191}. However, unlike patient\is{patient} or beneficiary\is{beneficiary} objects, associative objects may not be questioned with wétin ‘what’ or údat ‘who’. Instead, associative objects must be questioned with the corresponding adverbial question phrase or with the selective question element ús=káyn ‘\textsc{which’}, which questions modifiers.
Content 1: \gll Dán pɔ́sin go ánsa yú, “yɛ́s, na malérya e bin de \textbf{sík}.” | \gls that person POT answer 2SG.INDP yes FOC malaria 3SG.SBJ PST IPFV sick | \glt ‘That person would reply to you “yes, it’s malaria that she was sick with”.’

Knowledge Point: Hence the clause e de sík fíba \textsc{‘3sg.sbj} \textsc{ipfv} be sick fever’ = ‘she’s sick (with) fever’ cannot be questioned as *wétin e de sík ‘what \textsc{3sg.sbj} \textsc{ipfv} be.sick’ = ‘what is she sick (with)?’ Rather, the question must be phrased as in \REF{ex:key:1192}:
Content 1: \gll \'{U}s=káyn \textbf{sík} e de \textbf{sík}? | \gls Q=kind sickness 3SG.SBJ IPFV be.sick | \glt ‘What kind of sickness does she have?’

Knowledge Point: Aside from that, the use of cognate objects provides an important means of expressing emphasis \is{emphasis}in pragmatically marked, emphatic contexts such as (\ref{ex:key:1195}–\ref{ex:key:1196}). Emphatic cognate objects are frequently preceded by the indefinite determiner wán ‘one, a’ which provides emphasis in other contexts as well (e.g. in the context of negative indefinite phrases, cf. \ref{ex:key:575}):
Content 1: \gll Dɛn bin \textbf{fáyn} \textbf{wán} \textbf{fáyn}. | \gls 3PL PST be.fine one fineness | \glt ‘They were really fine.’
Content 2: \gll Dán torí bin de \textbf{swít} mí \textbf{wán} \textbf{swít}. | \gls that story PST IPFV be.tasty 1SG.INDP one tastiness | \glt ‘I really enjoyed that story.’
Content 3: \gll \textbf{Nó} tɔ́k \textbf{nó} \textbf{wán} wɔ́d! | \gls NEG talk NEG one word | \glt ‘Don’t say a single word!’

Knowledge Point: The cognate object dáy ‘death’ also appears as a cognate object to the verb dáy ‘die’ in emphatic contexts like \REF{ex:key:1197}:
Content 1: \gll \'{E}y, dán káyn spɛ́tikul, a \textbf{dáy} \textbf{dáy}. | \gls INTJ that kind glasses 1SG.SBJ die death | \glt ‘Hey, [if I had] that kind of glasses, I would surely die.’

Knowledge Point: The bulk of Pichi verbs can occur with one as well as two objects\is{objects}. The primacy of the object next to the verb – which is usually animate and has the role of recipient\is{recipient} or beneficiary – is evident in double-object constructions involving two object pronouns. The presence of two pronominal objects is ungrammatical if the clitic object pronoun =an is preceded by the low-toned personal pronoun una/unu ‘\textsc{2pl}’ or another \textsc{3sg.obj} pronoun =an (for details, see \sectref{sec:3.3}, on tone-conditioned suppletive allomorphy). In such cases, it is the patient object that remains unexpressed. Compare the double-object construction in \REF{ex:key:1199} with the ungrammatical example \REF{ex:key:1200} and sentence \REF{ex:key:1201}. In the latter example, the \textsc{3sg.obj} theme\is{theme} object =an remains unexpressed:
Content 1: \gll Yu gɛ́fɔ sɛ́n \textbf{wí=an}. | \gls 2SG have.to send 1PL.INDP=3SG.OBJ | \glt ‘You have to send it to us.’
Content 2: Not found
Content 3: \gll A go gí \textbf{unu} tumɔ́ro. | \gls 1SG.SBJ POT give 2PL tomorrow | \glt ‘I’ll give you (it) tomorrow.’

Knowledge Point: In the type 1 double-object construction, the primary object to the right of the verb occupies the recipient role, while the secondary object that follows the recipient invariably takes on a patient \is{patient}role. This kind of construction is found with verbs expressing the transfer of an entity or an act of communication from the subject\is{subjects} to a recipient. All ditransitive communication and transfer verbs encountered in the corpus are listed in \REF{ex:key:1202}:
Content 1: Not found

Knowledge Point: Pichi has no SVCs of the \textsc{give} type in order to mark a recipient or beneficiary\is{beneficiary SVC}. In double-object constructions featuring transfer verbs, the primary object next to the verb always has the semantic role of recipient \REF{ex:key:1203}. With transfer and communication verbs, a beneficiary\is{associative preposition} is usually expressed in a PP\is{prepositional phrases} introduced by fɔ ‘\textsc{prep’} \REF{ex:key:1204}. Hence, double-object constructions are the only means of expressing the grammatical relation between the ditransitive verb, its subject, and its recipient and theme\is{theme} objects:
Content 1: \gll Mi mamá dás \textbf{mí} \textbf{sɔn} \textbf{regalo}. | \gls 1SG.POSS mother give.as.present 1SG.INDP some present | \glt ‘My mother gave me a present.’
Content 2: \gll Mi mamá dás \textbf{sɔn} \textbf{regalo} \textbf{fɔ} \textbf{mí}. | \gls 1SG.POSS mother give.as.present some present PREP 1SG.INDP | \glt ‘My mother gave (somebody) a present for me.’

Knowledge Point: The following two double-object constructions involve the transfer verb gí ‘give’ \REF{ex:key:1206} and the verb of communication púl (torí) ‘narrate (a story)’ \REF{ex:key:1207}:
Content 1: \gll Dɛn bin gí \textbf{mí} \textbf{beca}. | \gls 3PL PST give 1SG.INDP scholarship. | \glt ‘I was given a scholarship.’
Content 2: \gll Na ín e de kán púl \textbf{mí} \textbf{dán} \textbf{torí}. | \gls FOC 3SG.INDP 3SG.SBJ IPFV come pull 1SG.INDP that story | \glt ‘That’s when she comes to tell me that story.’

Knowledge Point: The verb sɛ́n ‘send, throw’ denotes a situation in which both a transfer and a motion event{\fff} co-occur. When sɛ́n is used in a double-object construction, the primary object is always a recipient \REF{ex:key:1208}.
Content 1: \gll E gɛ́fɔ sɛ́n \textbf{mí=an}. | \gls 3SG.SBJ have.to send 1SG.INDP=3SG.OBJ | \glt ‘He has to send/throw it to me.’

Knowledge Point: Like with other transfer verbs, the recipient of sɛ́n may not be expressed as a prepositional phrase. Where we do find a prepositional phrase (usually introduced by fɔ ‘\textsc{prep}’), it can therefore only denote a beneficiary {\fff}or a goal{\fff} but not a recipient {\fff}\REF{ex:key:1209}:
Content 1: \gll E gɛ́fɔ sɛ́n=an \textbf{fɔ} \textbf{yú}. | \gls 3SG.SBJ have.to send=3SG.OBJ PREP 2SG.INDP | \glt ‘He has to send it to (where) you (are).’ or ‘He has to send it for you.’ but not `He has to send it to you.'

Knowledge Point: Sentence \REF{ex:key:1210} features two type 2 double-object constructions. The verb dú ‘do’ takes the primary, beneficiary object mí ‘\textsc{1sg.indp}’ and the patient object sɔn fébɔ ‘a favour’. The verb wás ‘wash’ also takes mí ‘\textsc{1sg.indp}’ as the beneficiary object while klós dɛn ‘clothing’ functions as the patient object:
Content 1: \gll A wánt mék yu dú \textbf{mí} \textbf{sɔn} \textbf{fébɔ} mék yu wás \textbf{mí} \textbf{sɔn} \textbf{klós} \textbf{dɛn}. | \gls 1SG.SBJ want SBJV 2SG do 1SG.INDP some favour SBJV 2SG wash 1SG.INDP some clothing PL | \glt ‘I want you to do me a favour (and) wash some clothes for me.’

Knowledge Point: The semantic role of beneficiary may subsume a maleficiary\is{maleficiary}, i.e. the affected party of a socially unacceptable action. In \REF{ex:key:1211}, a worried mother explains why she has left her teenage daughter in Spain instead of bringing her along with her to Malabo. Also, compare the first object of tíf ‘steal’, the maleficiary mí ‘\textsc{1sg.indp}’ in \REF{ex:key:1212}:
Content 1: \gll A lɛ́f mi pikín na Panyá bikɔs a de fía sé dɛn go bɛlɛ́ \textbf{mí} \textbf{mi} \textbf{pikín}. | \gls 1SG.SBJ leave 1SG.POSS child LOC Spain because 1SG.SBJ IPFV fear QUOT 3PL POT impregnate 1SG.INDP 1SG.POSS child | \glt ‘I have left my child in Spain because I fear that she would fall pregnant on me.’
Content 2: \gll Dɛn tíf \textbf{mí} \textbf{mi} \textbf{sús}. | \gls 3PL steal 1SG.INDP 1SG.POSS shoe | \glt ‘They stole my shoes from me.’

Knowledge Point: We have seen that a recipient\is{recipient} must be expressed as an object in type 1 double-object constructions. In contrast to type 1 constructions, type 2 constructions alternate freely with constructions in which the beneficiary is expressed as a prepositional phrase introduced by the associative preposition fɔ ‘\textsc{prep}’. In fact, the alternative involving a prepositional phrase is more common than the corresponding double-object construction. Compare the type 2 double-object construction \REF{ex:key:1213} involving the verb bay ‘buy’ with the PP alternative \REF{ex:key:1214}:
Content 1: \gll \'{A}fta primera dama báy=an \textbf{wán} \textbf{motó}, (...) | \gls then first lady buy=3SG.OBJ one car (...) | \glt ‘Then the first lady bought him a car (...)’
Content 2: \gll \MakeUppercase{A} bin báy \textbf{wán} \textbf{motó} \textbf{fɔ} \textbf{mi} \textbf{mása}. | \gls SG.sbj PST buy one car PREP 1SG.POSS boss | \glt ‘I bought a car for my boss.’

Knowledge Point: The second type of type 2 construction involves the caused location verb pút ‘put’. Here, the primary object has the semantic role of goal,\is{goal} while the secondary object fulfills a theme\is{theme} role. In \REF{ex:key:1215}, the primary object of pút is the goal object =an ‘\textsc{3sg.obj}’, while the secondary object saldo ‘(mobile phone) credit’ is the theme\is{theme}. Sentence \REF{ex:key:1216} also features the goal object =an ‘\textsc{3sg.obj}’, while the theme object is cacahuete ‘groundnut’:
Content 1: \gll Yu gɛ́t móvil, yu dɔ́n pút=\textbf{an} \textbf{saldo}? | \gls 2SG get mobile 2SG PRF put=3SG.OBJ credit | \glt ‘Do you have a mobile-phone, have you put credit into it?’
Content 2: \gll A báy dán dís tín, sɔn smɔ́l pépa, dɛn de pút=\textbf{an} \textbf{cacahuete}. | \gls 1SG.SBJ buy that this thing some small paper 3PL IPFV put=3SG.OBJ peanut | \glt ‘I bought that thing, a small paper, they put peanuts into it.’

Knowledge Point: However, the corpus contains many more examples of pút{}-constructions, in which the goal role is expressed through a locative construction rather than a primary object. Likewise, there is no sentence in the data in which the goal object of pút is a full noun. The locative construction may be a PP \REF{ex:key:1217} or involve a locative noun \REF{ex:key:1218}. Unlike a few other verbs with a motion\is{motion verbs} component (cf. \sectref{sec:8.1.4}), the goal of pút cannot be expressed as a complement of the V2 of a motion-direction SVC (e.g. *a pút=an gó na glás \{\textsc{1sg.sbj} put=\textsc{3sg.obj} go \textsc{loc} glass\} = ‘I put it into the glass’):
Content 1: \gll Dɛn kin pút=an \textbf{fɔ} \textbf{glás}. | \gls 3PL HAB put=3SG.OBJ PREP glass | \glt ‘They put it into the glass.’
Content 2: \gll \MakeUppercase{A} dɔ́n \textbf{pút} mi búk \textbf{ínsay}. | \gls 1SG.SBJ PRF put 1SG.POSS book inside | \glt ‘I have put my book inside.’

Knowledge Point: There is a preference to interpret a PP introduced by fɔ ‘\textsc{prep}’ as a beneficiary \is{beneficiary}in pút{}-double-object constructions, particularly where an object pronoun theoretically allows for both interpretations as in \REF{ex:key:1219}. A sentence like \REF{ex:key:1218} above, which involves a locative noun\is{locative nouns} (i.e. ínsay ‘inside’) is therefore preferred to avoid ambiguity. Nevertheless, an alternative with a prepositional phrase involving the general locative preposition na may also be exploited to the same end \REF{ex:key:1220}:
Content 1: \gll A dɔ́n pút granát \textbf{fɔr=an}. | \gls 1SG.SBJ PRF put peanut PREP=3SG.OBJ | \glt ‘I have put peanuts [somewhere] for her.’
Content 2: \gll \MakeUppercase{A} dɔ́n \textbf{pút} mi búk \textbf{ínsay}. | \gls 1SG.SBJ PRF put 1SG.POSS book inside | \glt ‘I have put my book inside.’
Content 3: \gll A dɔ́n pút granát \textbf{na} \textbf{ín}. | \gls 1SG.SBJ PRF put peanut LOC 3SG.INDP | \glt ‘I have put peanuts into it.’

Knowledge Point: Type 3 double-object construction involve verbs that may take associative objects (cf. \tabref{tab:key:9.9} above). Type 3 constructions differ from type 1 and type 2 constructions in that the primary object occupies the semantic role of patient. The secondary object is an associative object which may alternatively be expressed without any syntactic rearrangement through the mere insertion of a preposition, serial verb, or any other element between the two objects. The associative objects in type 3 constructions may therefore be paraphrased with the same means as associative objects in single-object constructions. Compare the double-object construction in \REF{ex:key:1222} with the single-object construction involving a PP in \REF{ex:key:1223}:\is{adjuncts}
Content 1: \gll Na lɛk sé yu fúlɔp \textbf{di} \textbf{glás} \textbf{watá}? | \gls FOC like QUOT 2SG fill DEF glás water | \glt ‘As if you filled this glass with water?’
Content 2: \gll E fúlɔp \textbf{di} \textbf{glás} \textbf{wet} \textbf{watá}. | \gls 3SG.SBJ fill.up DEF glass with water | \glt ‘She filled the glass with water.’

Knowledge Point: In the majority of cases, reflexivity is expressed through an object NP consisting of the pronominal and reflexive anaphor sɛ́f ‘self’ and a preceding possessive pronoun with the same person and number as the subject{\fff}. Sometimes, the body part{\fff} nouns skín ‘body’, bɔ́di ‘body’, and héd ‘head’ are also employed as reflexive anaphors in the same syntactic position as sɛ́f. A clause featuring a reflexive object NP indicates that the subject does something to her- or himself. The corpus only contains clauses in which subjects serve as antecedents to the reflexive anaphor, cf. \REF{ex:key:1224}:
Content 1: \gll Dán gál e kin fíks \textbf{in} \textbf{sɛ́f}, pént \textbf{in} \textbf{sɛ́f}. | \gls that girl 3SG.SBJ HAB fix 3SG.POSS self paint 3SG.POSS self | \glt ‘That girl habitually fixes herself up, paints herself [puts on make up].’

Knowledge Point: Compare wɛ́r ‘dress (up)’ in an explicitly reflexive clause \REF{ex:key:1230} and a clause in which reflexivity remains unexpressed \REF{ex:key:1231}:
Content 1: \gll Toichoa \textbf{wɛ́r} \textbf{in} \textbf{sɛ́f}. | \gls NAME wear 3SG.POSS self | \glt ‘Toichoa has/is dressed up.’
Content 2: \gll A \textbf{wɛ́r}. | \gls 1SG.SBJ wear | \glt ‘I’m dressed/have got dressed.’

Knowledge Point: Next to its use as a reflexive anaphor, the pronominal sɛ́f ‘self’ also serves as a reciprocal pronominal with plural referents. In sentence \REF{ex:key:1232}, the reciprocal NP is an object to the verb sláp ‘slap’, in \REF{ex:key:1233} to the locative noun bifó ‘before’:
Content 1: \gll Dɛn de sláp \textbf{dɛn} \textbf{sɛ́f}. | \gls 3PL IPFV slap 3PL self | \glt ‘They’re slapping each other.’
Content 2: \gll Pero dɛn nó sidɔ́n bifó \textbf{dɛn} \textbf{sɛ́f}. | \gls but 3PL NEG sit.down before 3PL self | \glt ‘But they’re not sitting in front of each other.’

Knowledge Point: Reflexive and reciprocal meaning may be disambiguated through contextual factors, i.e. verb meaning and the presence of plural referents. The occurrence of compound personal pronouns indicating dual number (i.e. dɛn-ɔl-tú ‘the two of them’) as in \REF{ex:key:1234} or universal inclusivity (dɛn-ɔ́l ‘all of them’) as in \REF{ex:key:1235} is also quite common in reciprocal contexts:
Content 1: \gll Fɔ́s na \textbf{dɛn-ɔl-tú} dɛn bin de abraza \textbf{dɛn} \textbf{sɛ́f}. | \gls first FOC 3PL.CPD-all.CPD-two 3PL PST IPFV embrace 3PL self | \glt ‘First it’s the two of them that were embracing each other.’
Content 2: Not found

Knowledge Point: Reciprocal relations within the \textsc{NP} find expression through the pronominal\is{possessive pronominal} yón as illustrated in \REF{ex:key:1236}:
Content 1: \gll Dɛn lúk \textbf{dɛn} \textbf{yón} fés. | \gls 3PL look 3PL own face | \glt ‘They looked at thier own faces.’

Knowledge Point: Pichi has three types of constructions for expressing weather phenomena. The first type of construction consists of an intransitive clause with the weather phenomenon in the subject\is{subjects} position. The verbs used in the first type of construction have a general meaning and also occur in other contexts including transitive clauses. Three sentences follow featuring the two weather verbs bló ‘blow’ (\ref{ex:key:1237}–\ref{ex:key:1238}) and bráyt ‘be bright’ \REF{ex:key:1239} and the weather nouns tináda ‘thunderstorm’, brís ‘air’, and sán ‘sun’:
Content 1: \gll Tináda de \textbf{bló}. | \gls thunderstorm IPFV blow | \glt ‘A thunderstorm is raging.’
Content 2: \gll Brís de \textbf{bló}. | \gls air IPFV blow | \glt ‘The wind is blowing.’
Content 3: \gll Di sán \textbf{bráyt}. | \gls DEF sun be.bright | \glt ‘The sun is bright/is shining.’

Knowledge Point: Sentence \REF{ex:key:1240} exemplifies the transitive usage of bló ‘blow’, sentence \REF{ex:key:1241} that of bráyt, here with the meaning ‘brighten, light up’:
Content 1: \gll Di ventilador de \textbf{bló} \textbf{mí}. | \gls DEF fan IPFV blow 1SG.INDP | \glt ‘The fan is blowing at me.’
Content 2: \gll Di sán \textbf{bráyt} \textbf{di} \textbf{dé}. | \gls DEF sun brighten DEF day | \glt ‘The sun lit up the sky.’

Knowledge Point: In expressions where reference is made to the general atmospheric condition, the noun dé ‘day, weather’ appears in the subject\is{subjects} position instead of a specific natural element. This usage is exemplified in the following three sentences and also in \REF{ex:key:1241} above:
Content 1: \gll Di sán \textbf{bráyt} \textbf{di} \textbf{dé}. | \gls DEF sun brighten DEF day | \glt ‘The sun lit up the sky.’

Knowledge Point: The second type of construction also involves an intransitive clause but it features the expletive subject\is{expletive} pronoun e ‘\textsc{3sg.sbj}’ rather than a weather noun. This construction is limited to a single intransitive verb, namely fɔ́l ‘rain’, which exclusively functions as a weather verb \REF{ex:key:1245}. The verb fɔ́l may, however, also occur in the first type of construction, together with the weather noun rén ‘rain’ in subject position \REF{ex:key:1246}:
Content 1: \gll A de sí di dé lɛkɛ sé \textbf{e} wánt \textbf{fɔ́l}. | \gls 1SG.SBJ IPFV see DEF day like QUOT 3SG.SBJ want rain | \glt ‘I think the weather is like it’s going to rain.’
Content 2: \gll A bin chɛ́k sé \textbf{rén} go \textbf{fɔ́l}. | \gls 1SG.SBJ PST check QUOT rain POT rain | \glt ‘I thought it would rain.’

Knowledge Point: Body states are expressed in constructions involving transitive (cf. 1a–1c in \tabref{tab:key:9.11}) and intransitive (2a–2c) clauses. Type 1 constructions in the table involve transitive clauses. In type 1a constructions, the affected body part\is{} is found in the subject\is{subjects} position, while the experiencer\is{experiencer} is in the object position. This construction is the preferred one for expressing pain and hurt. The verb is either of the dynamic experiential verbs hát ‘hurt’ or pén ‘pain’ (\ref{ex:key:1249}–\ref{ex:key:1251}).
Content 1: \gll Mi \textbf{bɛlɛ́} de \textbf{hát} mí. | \gls 1SG.POSS belly IPFV hurt 1SG.INDP | \glt ‘My stomach is hurting me.’
Content 2: \gll Mi \textbf{tít} de \textbf{pén} mí. | \gls 1SG.POSS tooth IPFV pain 1SG.INDP | \glt ‘My tooth is paining me.’

Knowledge Point: Type 1c constructions in \tabref{tab:key:9.11} are the mirror-image of type 1b constructions. The experiencer is in the subject position, while the body state or sensation is expressed as a deverbal noun in the object position. Hunger, thirst, and sleep(iness) can be expressed by this construction with the dynamic body state verbs fíl ‘feel’ (\ref{ex:key:1255}–\ref{ex:key:1256}). Hunger and thirst can also be expressed in combination with the verb sɔ́fa ‘suffer, endure’ \REF{ex:key:1257}:
Content 1: \gll A de \textbf{fíl} \textbf{hángri}, A de \textbf{fíl} \textbf{slíp}. | \gls 1SG.SBJ IPFV feel hungry 1SG.SBJ IPFV feel sleep | \glt ‘I’m feeling hungry, I’m feeling sleepy.’
Content 2: \gll A \textbf{fíl} di pikín in \textbf{pén}. | \gls 1SG.SBJ feel DEF child 3SG.POSS pain | \glt ‘I went into labour.’ [Lit. ‘I felt the child’s pain].’
Content 3: \gll A \textbf{sɔ́fa} wán \textbf{hángri} na dán kɔ́ntri. | \gls 1SG.SBJ suffer one hunger LOC that country | \glt ‘I endured extraordinary hunger in that country.’

Knowledge Point: Proof for the nominal status of the body state in the constructions above is provided by sentences \REF{ex:key:1256} and \REF{ex:key:1257}. In the former example, we find a dislocated possessive construction\is{possessive constructions} in the object position of fíl. In the latter example, the indefinite determiner wán ‘one, a’ precedes hángri ‘hunger’, the object of sɔ́fa ‘endure’.
Content 1: \gll A \textbf{fíl} di pikín in \textbf{pén}. | \gls 1SG.SBJ feel DEF child 3SG.POSS pain | \glt ‘I went into labour.’ [Lit. ‘I felt the child’s pain].’
Content 2: \gll A \textbf{sɔ́fa} wán \textbf{hángri} na dán kɔ́ntri. | \gls 1SG.SBJ suffer one hunger LOC that country | \glt ‘I endured extraordinary hunger in that country.’

Knowledge Point: Type 2 constructions involve intransitive clauses. In type 2a, the experiencer appears in the subject position. The body state is instantiated in a dynamic verb. Once more, the basic body states of hunger and thirst can be expressed in this way (\ref{ex:key:1260}–\ref{ex:key:1261}). However, other transient body states like sík ‘be sick’ also appear in this construction \REF{ex:key:1262}:
Content 1: \gll A \textbf{de} \textbf{hángri}. | \gls 1SG.SBJ IPFV be.hungry | \glt ‘I’m hungry.’
Content 2: \gll A \textbf{de} \textbf{tɔ́sti}. | \gls 1SG.SBJ IPFV be.thirsty | \glt ‘I’m thirsty.’
Content 3: \gll Wán dé wán pikín bin \textbf{de} \textbf{sík}. | \gls one day one child PST IPFV sick | \glt ‘One day, a certain child was sick.’

Knowledge Point: In type 2b constructions, the body state verb is inchoative-stative. Compare táya ‘be tired’ \REF{ex:key:1263} wɛ́l ‘be well’ \REF{ex:key:1264}, bɛlfúl ‘be satiated’ \REF{ex:key:1265}, and hát ‘be hurt’ \REF{ex:key:1266}:
Content 1: \gll A \textbf{táya}. | \gls 1SG.SBJ be.tired | \glt ‘I’m tired.’
Content 2: \gll A \textbf{wɛ́l}. | \gls 1SG.SBJ well | \glt ‘I’m well.’
Content 3: \gll A \textbf{bɛlfúl}. | \gls 1SG.SBJ be.satiated | \glt ‘I’m full.’
Content 4: \gll Di gál \textbf{hát}. | \gls DEF girl hurt | \glt ‘The girl is hurt.’

Knowledge Point: Type 2c constructions are intransitive copula clauses. The body state verb appears as an adjective complement\is{complements} to the locative-existential\is{copula!locative-existential} copula dé \textsc{‘be.loc’} \REF{ex:key:1267}. The property items gúd ‘be well’, bád ‘be bad’, and fáyn ‘be fine’ appear in such predicate adjective constructions when they express a transient body state rather than an (intrinsic) value (cf. \sectref{sec:7.6.5}):
Content 1: \gll Dán tɛ́n a \textbf{dé} \textbf{fáyn}. | \gls that time 1SG.SBJ BE.LOC fine | \glt ‘That time, I was fine.’

Knowledge Point: Subjects are normally expressed overtly but subject omission\is{subject omission} (indicated by {\emptyset}) occasionally occurs with verbs with impersonal reference, as with fít ‘can’ in an excerpt from a procedural text \REF{ex:key:1270}:
Content 1: Not found

Knowledge Point: The following two sentences are uttered in sequence by the same speaker. Compare the ambiguous function of sé in \REF{ex:key:1271b}, which is introduced by sé, with (a) where sé is firmly integrated into the sentence as a quotative marker:
Content 1: \gll \textbf{Sé} chico, dí tín nó go dú mí. | \gls QUOT boy this thing NEG POT do 1SG.INDP | \glt ‘(He said) “man, this won’t do for me”.’

Knowledge Point: In principle, objects need not be overtly expressed. In practice, highly transitive verbs are unlikely to appear without a patient object, even if the object is non-specific. The verb bló ‘give a blow’ in \REF{ex:key:1272} denotes a situation which implies a high degree of volition and instigation by an agent. Equally, the situation involves no notion of affectedness of the agent (cf. \citealt{Naess2007}):
Content 1: \gll A \textbf{bló} \textbf{dí} \textbf{pikín}. | \gls 1SG.SBJ give.blow this child | \glt ‘I gave this child [guy] a blow.’

Knowledge Point: When bló occurs without an object it is understood to be the homophonous bló ‘rest, relax’ \REF{ex:key:1273}, a verb which is lower on the transitivity scale, but may also be used transitively \REF{ex:key:1274}, due to its status as a labile\is{labile verbs} experiential verb:
Content 1: \gll A de \textbf{bló} ɔ a de \textbf{rɛ́s}. | \gls 1SG.SBJ IPFV relax or 1SG.SBJ IPFV rest | \glt ‘I’m relaxing or I’m resting.’
Content 2: \gll Mék a \textbf{bló} \textbf{dí} \textbf{pɔ́sin} mék e fít recupera. | \gls SBJV 1SG.SBJ relax this person SBJV 3SG.SBJ can recover | \glt ‘Let me make this person rest for her to be able to recover.’

Knowledge Point: When highly transitive verbs are used in a context of non-specificity, they usually occur with generic noun\is{generic nouns}s as objects. Compare the non-specific object sɔn tín ‘something’ of the highly transitive verb híb ‘throw (away)’ \REF{ex:key:1275} and pɔ́sin ‘person’, object of nák ‘hit’ \REF{ex:key:1276}:
Content 1: \gll (...) yu \textbf{híb} \textbf{sɔn} \textbf{tín} fɔ grɔ́n (...) | \gls (...) 2SG throw some thing PREP ground (...) | \glt ‘(...) (if) you throw something on the ground (...)’
Content 2: \gll (...) na ín e de \textbf{nák} \textbf{pɔ́sin}. | \gls (...) FOC 3SG.INDP 3SG.SBJ IPFV hit person | \glt ‘(...) that’s why she’s hitting somebody.’

Knowledge Point: The objects of effected-object verbs come into existence through the situation denoted by the verb. They are not affected or changed by the situation denoted by the verb like the patient objects of more prototypically transitive verbs. The non-specific effected objects of verbs of speech and sound emission often occur without a speech- and sound-denoting noun or pronoun. Consider the following use of tɔ́k ‘say, talk’ in a transitive \REF{ex:key:1277} and in an intransitive clause \REF{ex:key:1278}:
Content 1: \gll Bikɔs yu dɔ́n \textbf{tɔ́k} \textbf{wán} \textbf{bád} \textbf{tɔ́k}, e sé “gɔ́d háma yu mɔ́t!” | \gls because 2SG PRF talk one bad word 3SG.SBJ QUOT God hammer 2SG mouth | \glt ‘Because you have said something bad, she says “may God hammer your mouth!”’
Content 2: \gll Sé “a bin sí bɔt a nó fít \textbf{tɔ́k}.” | \gls QUOT 1SG.SBJ PST see but 1SG.SBJ NEG can talk. | \glt ‘(He) said “I saw (it) but I couldn’t talk”.’

Knowledge Point: Another verb that may be used in this way is síng ‘síng’ \REF{ex:key:1279}:
Content 1: \gll E de \textbf{síng} na Píchi. | \gls 3SG.SBJ IPFV síng LOC Pichi | \glt ‘He sings in Pichi.’

Knowledge Point: Likewise, the effected non-specific objects of verbs denoting a process of production may remain unexpressed. Compare só ‘sew’ (\ref{ex:key:1280}–\ref{ex:key:1281}) and kúk ‘cook’ (\ref{ex:key:1282}–\ref{ex:key:1283}) in the transitive and intransitive sentence pairs below:
Content 1: \gll (...) wé yu nó nó to fíks wán klós, to \textbf{só} \textbf{wán} \textbf{klós} (...) | \gls (...) SUB 2SG NEG know to fix one clothing to sew one clothing (...) | \glt ‘(...) when you don’t know how to fix a dress, to sew a dress (...)’
Content 2: \gll Di sastre de \textbf{só}. | \gls DEF tailor IPFV sew | \glt ‘The tailor is sewing.’
Content 3: \gll E kin \textbf{kúk} \textbf{súp}. | \gls 3SG.SBJ HAB cook soup | \glt ‘He cooks soups.’
Content 4: \gll Di húman kán na hós di áwa wé a de \textbf{kúk}. | \gls DEF woman come LOC house DEF hour SUB 1SG.SBJ IPFV cook | \glt ‘The woman came to the house at the time when I was cooking.’

Knowledge Point: Affected-agent verbs are also lower on the scale of semantic transitivity than prototypical transitive verbs, because the actors are themselves affected by the situation in addition to the undergoer. In this group, we find transitive motion verbs\is{motion verbs} like rích ‘reach, arrive’ (\ref{ex:key:1284}–\ref{ex:key:1285}) and gó ‘go (away)’ (\ref{ex:key:1286}–\ref{ex:key:1287}), whose goal\is{goal} objects may remain unexpressed:
Content 1: \gll Yu nɛ́a \textbf{rích} \textbf{Lubá}? | \gls 2SG NEG.PRF arrive PLACE | \glt ‘You’ve not yet been to Luba?’
Content 2: \gll E dɔ́n \textbf{rích}. | \gls 3SG.SBJ PRF arrive | \glt ‘He has arrived.’
Content 3: \gll Bueno, a de \textbf{gó} \textbf{mákit} náw. | \gls good 1SG.SBJ IPFV go market now | \glt ‘Alright, I’m going to the market now.’

Knowledge Point: Typical affected-agent verbs are the ingestive verbs chɔ́p \REF{ex:key:1288} ‘eat’ and dríng ‘drink’ \REF{ex:key:1289}. These two transitive verbs are usually encountered without a patient\is{patient} object when its reference is non-specific. Note that object omission with dríng in combination with a habitual reading renders the idiomatic meaning ‘habitually drink alcohol’:
Content 1: \gll A kán \textbf{chɔ́p}. | \gls 1SG.SBJ PFV eat | \glt ‘(Then) I ate.’
Content 2: \gll Dí pɔ́sin \textbf{de} \textbf{dríng}, na chak-mán. | \gls this person IPFV drink FOC drink.CPD-man | \glt ‘This person drinks, he’s a drunkard.’

Knowledge Point: When sí ‘see, perceive’ occurs without an object, its non-specific reading may translate as ‘understand’ or ‘witness’ (cf. e.g. \ref{ex:key:1278}). However, sí is also very often encountered in a non-specific context with a \textsc{3sg} object pronoun \REF{ex:key:1290} or an object \textsc{NP} di tín ‘the thing’ \REF{ex:key:1291}. Both of these objects are only faintly referential and therefore appear to function as dummy\is{dummy nouns} objects in very much the same way as non-referential subjects with expletive verbs (cf. \sectref{sec:9.2.4}):
Content 1: \gll Sé “a bin sí bɔt a nó fít \textbf{tɔ́k}.” | \gls QUOT 1SG.SBJ PST see but 1SG.SBJ NEG can talk. | \glt ‘(He) said “I saw (it) but I couldn’t talk”.’
Content 2: \gll Yɛ́s, yu de \textbf{sí=an}? | \gls yes 2SG IPFV see=3SG.OBJ | \glt ‘Yes, do you understand?’
Content 3: \gll Yu \textbf{sí} \textbf{di} \textbf{tín}? | \gls 2SG see DEF thing | \glt ‘You see?’

Knowledge Point: The cognition verb mɛ́mba often appears without an explicit object with its meaning of ‘remember’ \REF{ex:key:1292}:
Content 1: \gll A nó de \textbf{mɛ́mba}. | \gls 1SG.SBJ NEG IPFV remember | \glt ‘I don’t remember.’

Knowledge Point: However, when mɛ́mba occurs in a transitive clause, it is best translated as ‘think of’, both with a specific object \REF{ex:key:1293} and a non-specific one \REF{ex:key:1294}:
Content 1: \gll A kin \textbf{mɛ́mba} \textbf{yú} bɔkú. | \gls 1SG.SBJ HAB think 2SG.INDP much | \glt ‘I think of you a lot.’
Content 2: \gll Nó hambɔ́g mí, a de \textbf{mɛ́mba} \textbf{sɔn} \textbf{tín}! | \gls NEG bother 1SG.INDP 1SG.SBJ IPFV think some thing | \glt ‘Don’t bother me, I’m thinking about something!’

Knowledge Point: Likewise, verbs denoting physical activities often occur with unexpressed objects. Consider plé ‘play’ in \REF{ex:key:1295}:
Content 1: \gll Bɔt wi fít de \textbf{plé} a jám yú yu fɔdɔ́n. | \gls but 1PL can IPFV play 1SG.SBJ make.contact 2SG.INDP 2SG fall | \glt ‘But we could be playing [football], I hit you (and) you fall.’

Knowledge Point: The following examples involve the “body care” verbs wás ‘wash’ \REF{ex:key:1297}, báf ‘bathe’ \REF{ex:key:1298}, and wɛ́r ‘dress (up)’ \REF{ex:key:1231}. Note that wɛ́r takes an object in \REF{ex:key:1300} and still implies reflexivity:
Content 1: \gll Dɛn de kán sé dɛn kán \textbf{wás}. | \gls 3PL IPFV come QUOT 3PL come wash | \glt ‘They come to wash themselves.’
Content 2: \gll Yu dɔ́n \textbf{báf}? | \gls 2SG PRF bathe | \glt ‘Have you bathed?’
Content 3: \gll A \textbf{wɛ́r}. | \gls 1SG.SBJ wear | \glt ‘I’m dressed/have got dressed.’
Content 4: \gll Na lɛk if yu \textbf{wɛ́r} \textbf{sɔ́t} di gud-sáy wet di rɔn-sáy. | \gls FOC like if 2SG wear shirt DEF good.CPD-side with DEF wrong.CPD-side | \glt ‘That’s like if you put on a shirt the right way or inside out.’

Knowledge Point: The basic posture verbs slíp ‘lie (down), sleep’, tínap ‘stand (up)’ and sidɔ́n ‘sit (down)’ are never encountered with a reflexive pronoun in the corpus (cf. \sectref{sec:8.1.3} for an extensive treatment). In contrast, verbs denoting less prototypical postures, e.g. líng ‘lean over’ and bɛ́n ‘bend (over)’ in (\ref{ex:key:1303}–\ref{ex:key:1304}), as well as those denoting other types of body-related events, e.g. háyd ‘hide’ in (\ref{ex:key:1305}–\ref{ex:key:1306}) are found with or without reflexive pronouns:
Content 1: \gll E de wáka e \textbf{bɛ́n}. | \gls 3SG.SBJ IPFV walk 3SG.SBJ bend | \glt ‘He is walking stooped over.’
Content 2: \gll Sé dɛn \textbf{líng} dɛn sɛ́f ɔ fɔ lɛk háw dɛn \textbf{bɛ́n} dɛn sɛ́f? | \gls QUOT 3PL lean 3PL self or PREP like how 3PL bend 3PL self | \glt ‘That they’re leaning (onto something) or how they’re stooped over?’
Content 3: \gll A kán \textbf{háyd} ínsay hós. | \gls 1SG.SBJ PFV hide inside house | \glt ‘(Then) I hid in the house.’
Content 4: \gll A \textbf{háyd} mi sɛ́f na hós. | \gls 1SG.SBJ hide 1SG.POSS self LOC house | \glt ‘I hid myself in the house.’

Knowledge Point: Verbs with an inherently reciprocal meaning may appear with or without the reflexive and reciprocal anaphor sɛ́f ‘self’. Consider the use of reciprocal sɛ́f with the sexual act denoting verbs nák ‘knock’ \REF{ex:key:1310} and slíp ‘sleep with’ \REF{ex:key:1311}, as well as the unexpressed reciprocal pronoun in \REF{ex:key:1312}. These examples also illustrate that sexual act denoting verbs, including highly transitive ones like nák, do not imply a male agent in Pichi:
Content 1: \gll (...) wi \textbf{nák} \textbf{wi} \textbf{sɛ́f}. | \gls (...) 1PL knock 1PL self | \glt ‘(...) we knocked each other.’
Content 2: \gll \'{I}nsay di motó, na dé unu de \textbf{slíp} \textbf{unu} \textbf{sɛ́f}? | \gls inside DEF car FOC there 2PL IPFV sleep 2PL self | \glt ‘In the car, that’s where you sleep with each other?’
Content 3: \gll Una \textbf{slíp}? | \gls 2PL sleep | \glt ‘You slept (with each other)?’

Knowledge Point: Conversely, the inherently reciprocal verbs of social interaction mít ‘meet’ and mítɔp ‘meet’ do not normally occur with the anaphor sɛ́f (\ref{ex:key:1313}–\ref{ex:key:1314}):
Content 1: \gll E tɛ́l mí sé wi kin \textbf{mítɔp} ínsay wán motó. | \gls 3SG.SBJ tell 1SG.INDP QUOT 1PL HAB meet inside one car | \glt ‘He told me “we usually meet inside a car”.’
Content 2: \gll \'{A}fta wi kán \textbf{mít} layk wán seis años después. | \gls then 1PL PFV meet like one six years afterwards | \glt ‘Then we met some six years later.’

Knowledge Point: Nevertheless, like other inherently reciprocal verbs, mít and mítɔp may take part in a reciprocal alternation (cf. also fɛ́t ‘fight’ in \ref{ex:key:1090}). The two participants may be expressed as coordinate subject{\fff}s in an intransitive clause while reciprocity is understood. Compare the transitive use of mít ‘meet’ in \REF{ex:key:1315}, with its intransitive use with two coordinate subjects in \REF{ex:key:1316}:
Content 1: Not found
Content 2: \gll Pero e \textbf{mít} \textbf{mi} \textbf{gran-má}. | \gls but 3SG.SBJ meet 1SG.POSS grand-ma | \glt ‘But he met my grandmother.’
Content 3: \gll \textbf{Mí} \textbf{wet} \textbf{Djunais} wi mítɔp. | \gls 1SG.INDP with NAME 1PL meet | \glt ‘Me and Djunais (we) met.’

Knowledge Point: Causative and permissive constructions are formed with the two verbs mék ‘make’ and lɛ́f ‘leave, permit’. Examples (\ref{ex:key:1319}–\ref{ex:key:1320}) present their use in non-causative transitive clauses:
Content 1: \gll Yu fít \textbf{mék} mí wán café? | \gls 2SG can make 1SG.INDP one coffee | \glt ‘Can you make me a coffee?’
Content 2: \gll A sé a nó fít \textbf{lɛ́f}=an. | \gls 1SG.SBJ QUOT 1SG.SBJ NEG can leave=3SG.OBJ | \glt ‘I said I can’t leave her (behind).’

Knowledge Point: Two types of causative constructions can be distinguished on formal grounds (cf. \citealt{Yakpo2012a}, \citealt{Yakpo2017a}). The most common type of causative construction in Pichi inolves a “balanced” structure \citep{Cristofaro2003}. The causative event is expressed in two finite clauses and the causative verb and the verb-of-effect are linked in a relation of subordination\is{subordination}. Sentence \REF{ex:key:1321} below features the (inanimate) causer NP lotería ‘lottery’, the causative main verb mék ‘make’, the causee NP mi mɔní ‘my money’, and the subordinate verb-of-effect bɔkú ‘be much’. The subordinate status of the effect situation is evident through its appearance in a subjunctive clause introduced by the modal complementiser and subjunctive marker mék ‘\textsc{sbjv}’:
Content 1: \gll Lotería dɔ́n \textbf{mék} \textbf{mék} mi mɔní \textbf{bɔkú}. | \gls lottery PRF make SBJV 1SG.POSS money be.much | \glt ‘The lottery has made my money become a lot.’

Knowledge Point: The second type of causative construction involves a “deranked” \citep{Cristofaro2003} or “reduced” \citep{Lehmann1988} structure and argument sharing. The causee (here =an \textsc{‘3sg.obj’}) is the syntactic object of the causative main verb mék and at once the notional subject of the subordinate verb-of-effect gó as in \REF{ex:key:1322}. This construction is marginal in terms of frequency, and only attested with Group 1 speakers (cf. \sectref{sec:1.3}). I could not identify any semantic differences between the two types of caustive constructions:
Content 1: \gll A go \textbf{mék}=an \textbf{gó} tumɔ́ro. | \gls 1SG.SBJ POT make=3SG.OBJ go tomorrow | \glt ‘I’ll make him go tomorrow.’

Knowledge Point: Both transitive and intransitive verbs may be causativised. Example \REF{ex:key:1323} features a causative construction with the intransitive verb of effect bɛ́lch ‘belch’ and \REF{ex:key:1324} one with the transitive verb wích ‘bewitch’. Like all complement clauses, the subjunctive clause in these constructions can optionally be introduced by the quotative marker sé ‘\textsc{quot}’ in addition to mék ‘\textsc{sbjv}’ \REF{ex:key:1324}:
Content 1: \gll A níd fɔ drink sɔn tín wé de mék \textbf{mék} a \textbf{bɛ́lch} | \gls 1SG.SBJ need PREP drink some thing SUB IPFV make SBJV 1SG.SBJ belch | \glt ‘I need to drink something that will make me belch.’
Content 2: \gll Na ín mék \textbf{sé} \textbf{mék} dɛn \textbf{wích}=an. | \gls FOC 3SG.INDP make QUOT SBJV 3PL bewitch=3SG.OBJ | \glt ‘That’s why he was bewitched.’
Content 3: \gll Na ín mék \textbf{sé} \textbf{mék} dɛn \textbf{wích}=an. | \gls FOC 3SG.INDP make QUOT SBJV 3PL bewitch=3SG.OBJ | \glt ‘That’s why he was bewitched.’

Knowledge Point: Sentence \REF{ex:key:1325} illustrates the two options for rendering causative meaning with labile verbs\is{labile verbs}. Before the comma, the verb drɔ́ngo ‘be/get drunk’ is used as a transitive and causative verb followed by the patient\is{patient} object pronoun =an ‘\textsc{3sg.obj}’. In the second half of the sentence, causative meaning is expressed periphrastically through the mék causative construction. When the second option is used, the speaker may want to express that causation is less direct. Meanwhile, the use of the transitive variant of a labile verb implies a direct, possibly even physical implication of the causer:
Content 1: \gll A \textbf{drɔ́ngor}=an, a \textbf{mék} mék e \textbf{drɔ́ngo}. | \gls 1SG.SBJ get.drunk=3SG.OBJ 1SG.SBJ make SBJV 3SG.SBJ be.drunk | \glt ‘I got him drunk, I made him drunk.’

Knowledge Point: There are no restrictions on negation\is{negation} in causative constructions. The causative verb in the main clause \REF{ex:key:1327} as well as the verb of effect in the subordinate clause \REF{ex:key:1328} may be negated:
Content 1: \gll Pút di watá pero \textbf{nó} \textbf{mék} mék e \textbf{fɔdɔ́n} nado. | \gls put DEF water but NEG make SBJV 3SG.SBJ fall outside | \glt ‘Put the water (inside) but don’t make it fall outside (the vessel).’
Content 2: \gll Fít sifta ín sóté tú tɛ́n \textbf{mék} mék dán smɔ́l smɔ́l watá dɛn \textbf{nó} \textbf{lɛ́f}. | \gls can sieve 3SG.INDP until two time make SBJV that small small water PL NEG remain | \glt ‘(You) can sift it up to two times to make none of that little water remain.’

Knowledge Point: Hence, the subordinate clauses in \REF{ex:key:1329} and \REF{ex:key:1330} feature regular TMA marking via dɔ́n ‘\textsc{prf}’ and de ‘\textsc{ipfv}’, respectively, instead of subjunctive marking. Nonetheless, even these idioms are occasionally conceived of as regular causative constructions with the reduced TMA marking characteristic of subjunctive subordinate clauses (cf. \ref{ex:key:1324} above):
Content 1: \gll Na ín \textbf{mék} dɔtí \textbf{dɔ́n} plɛ́nte. | \gls FOC 3SG.INDP make dirty PRF plenty | \glt ‘That’s why the dirt has become so much.’
Content 2: \gll Wétin \textbf{mék} yu nó \textbf{de} wók tidé? | \gls what make 2SG NEG IPFV work today | \glt ‘Why aren’t you working today?’
Content 3: \gll Na ín mék \textbf{sé} \textbf{mék} dɛn \textbf{wích}=an. | \gls FOC 3SG.INDP make QUOT SBJV 3PL bewitch=3SG.OBJ | \glt ‘That’s why he was bewitched.’

Knowledge Point: The subjunctive marker mék also introduces the complement clauses\is{complement clauses} of other main verbs, which – like the causative verb mék ‘make’ – induce deontic modality over their subordinate clauses. One such main verb is wánt ‘want’ \REF{ex:key:1331} (cf. \sectref{sec:10.5.5} for a full treatment of the functions of mék ‘\textsc{sbjv’} in subordinate clauses):
Content 1: \gll \'{U}s=sáy yu \textbf{wánt} \textbf{mék} di smók kɔmɔ́t? | \gls Q=side 2SG want SBJV DEF smoke come.out | \glt ‘Where do you want the smoke to come out?’

Knowledge Point: Consider the following two permissives and compare them with a causative construction like \REF{ex:key:1323} above. In \REF{ex:key:1323}, the causative verb mék takes no object pronoun mí ‘\textsc{1sg.indp}’ that is co-referential with the subject a ‘\textsc{1sg.sbj’} of the subjunctive clause.
Content 1: \gll A níd fɔ drink sɔn tín wé de mék \textbf{mék} a \textbf{bɛ́lch} | \gls 1SG.SBJ need PREP drink some thing SUB IPFV make SBJV 1SG.SBJ belch | \glt ‘I need to drink something that will make me belch.’
Content 2: \gll A níd fɔ drink sɔn tín wé de mék \textbf{mék} a \textbf{bɛ́lch} | \gls 1SG.SBJ need PREP drink some thing SUB IPFV make SBJV 1SG.SBJ belch | \glt ‘I need to drink something that will make me belch.’

Knowledge Point: Sentence \REF{ex:key:1334} features the property item yún ‘be young’. The resultative causative equivalent in \REF{ex:key:1335} features the causer e ‘\textsc{3sg.sbj}’ = ‘it’ (i.e. ‘the clothing’), the causee yú ‘\textsc{2sg.indp}’, which is an object to lɛ́f ‘leave’, as well as the resultative complement yún ‘young’. The verb lɛ́f in these constructions may either be used as an inchoative-stative verb, as in \REF{ex:key:1335}, or a dynamic verb, as in \REF{ex:key:1339} below, where lɛ́f is specified by de ‘\textsc{ipfv}’:
Content 1: \gll Dís húman \textbf{yún} yét. | \gls this woman be.young yet | \glt ‘This woman is still young.’
Content 2: \gll E \textbf{lɛ́f} yú \textbf{yún}. | \gls 3SG.SBJ leave 2SG.INDP be.young | \glt ‘It makes/made you (appear) young.’
Content 3: \gll E \textbf{lɛ́f} yú \textbf{yún}. | \gls 3SG.SBJ leave 2SG.INDP be.young | \glt ‘It makes/made you (appear) young.’
Content 4: \gll Di klós dɛn de \textbf{lɛ́f} yú \textbf{yun-bɔ́y}. | \gls DEF clothing PL IPFV leave 2SG.INDP be.young.CPD-boy | \glt ‘These clothes make you (appear) a young man.’

Knowledge Point: Example \REF{ex:key:1336} presents a non-causative predication involving the inchoative-stative property item kɔrɛ́t ‘be correct’. The resultative causative counterpart in \REF{ex:key:1337} features the force{\fff} causer{\fff} gɔ́d ‘God’, the causative verb lɛ́f ‘leave’, and the resultative complement kɔrɛ́t ‘(be) correct’:
Content 1: \gll Dí wán nó \textbf{kɔrɛ́t}. | \gls this one NEG be.correct | \glt ‘This one is not correct.’
Content 2: \gll Gɔ́d go \textbf{lɛ́f} di mán \textbf{kɔrɛ́t}. | \gls God POT leave DEF man be.correct | \glt ‘God will make this man righteous.’

Knowledge Point: Sentence \REF{ex:key:1338} is an equative clause{\fff} featuring the identity copula/focus marker na ‘\textsc{foc}’. The causative equivalent in \REF{ex:key:1339} once more features the resultative causative verb lɛ́f, as well as the compound noun and resultative complement yun-bɔ́y ‘young.\textsc{cpd}-boy’:
Content 1: \gll Di húman \textbf{na} \textbf{yun-gɛ́l}. | \gls DEF woman FOC be.young.CDP-girl | \glt ‘The woman is a young woman.’
Content 2: \gll Di klós dɛn de \textbf{lɛ́f} yú \textbf{yun-bɔ́y}. | \gls DEF clothing PL IPFV leave 2SG.INDP be.young.CPD-boy | \glt ‘These clothes make you (appear) a young man.’

Knowledge Point: An interesting semantic aspect of the use of resultative causatives is that they are not attested with human causers occupying the agent\is{agent} role. All recorded instances of resultative causatives feature inanimate force\is{force} causers in the subject\is{subjects} position. I assume that speakers prefer to employ causative constructions featuring mék ‘make’ where the causer is human, or where they intend to convey a notion of strong agency on the part of the causer even if it is inanimate (e.g. sentence \REF{ex:key:1321} above with the force causer lotería ‘lottery’ and the property item bɔkú ‘be much’ as a verb of effect).
Content 1: \gll Lotería dɔ́n \textbf{mék} \textbf{mék} mi mɔní \textbf{bɔkú}. | \gls lottery PRF make SBJV 1SG.POSS money be.much | \glt ‘The lottery has made my money become a lot.’

Knowledge Point: The verb pút ‘put’ is also used as a causative verb in a few instances in the corpus. In \REF{ex:key:1340} below, pút is employed like lɛ́f in \REF{ex:key:1335} and \REF{ex:key:1339} above in order to express the resultative causative equivalent of a non-causative equative clause{\fff}. The sentence contains the non-causative equative clause yu húman na bíg húman ‘your wife is an important woman’ and the causative equivalent pút yu sɛ́f bíg mán ‘make yourself an important man’:{\fff}
Content 1: \gll Ɛf yu húman \textbf{na} \textbf{bíg} \textbf{húman}, e hád fɔ \textbf{pút} yu sɛ́f \textbf{bíg} \textbf{mán}. | \gls if 2SG woman FOC big woman 3SG.SBJ hard PREP put 2SG self big man | \glt ‘If your wife is an important woman, it is difficult to make yourself an important man.’
Content 2: \gll E \textbf{lɛ́f} yú \textbf{yún}. | \gls 3SG.SBJ leave 2SG.INDP be.young | \glt ‘It makes/made you (appear) young.’
Content 3: \gll Di klós dɛn de \textbf{lɛ́f} yú \textbf{yun-bɔ́y}. | \gls DEF clothing PL IPFV leave 2SG.INDP be.young.CPD-boy | \glt ‘These clothes make you (appear) a young man.’

Knowledge Point: A backgrounding passive may be formed by using impersonal dɛn ‘\textsc{3pl’} in the subject position. To begin with, the \textsc{3pl} personal pronoun dɛn may be used generically to refer to a loosely specified collective. Example \REF{ex:key:1341} features the generic, impersonal use of dɛn in a transitive clause: \is{agent}
Content 1: \gll \textbf{Dɛn} de wɛ́r wáyt ɔ́p violeta dɔ́n. | \gls 3PL IPFV wear white up violet down | \glt ‘They [the pupils] wear white up (and) violet down.’

Knowledge Point: The following two sentences exemplify the pragmatic and syntactic rearrangements which go along with the use of the labile\is{labile verbs} property item strét ‘be straight, straighten’ in an intransitive \REF{ex:key:1343} and a transitive clause \REF{ex:key:1344}, respectively. In the intransitive clause, the subject\is{subjects} ród ‘road’ is patient\is{patient} to the inchoative-stative verb strét. In the transitive clause, impersonal dɛn in subject position denotes the backgrounded agent, while the patient ród is now in object position:
Content 1: \gll Di \textbf{ród} strét. | \gls DEF road be.straight | \glt ‘The road is straight.’
Content 2: \gll \textbf{Dɛn} dɔ́n strét di \textbf{ród}. | \gls 3PL PRF straighten DEF road | \glt ‘The road has been straightened.’

Knowledge Point: Impersonal dɛn always refers to an unspecified group of animate, usually human agents. The lower the agent is on the animacy scale, and hence its capacity of volition and instigation, the less likely it is to be referred to by impersonal dɛn. For example, \REF{ex:key:1345} sounds awkward, since the backgrounded agent is construed as animate and human. A situation involving a non-human agent like snék ‘snake’ is therefore more likely to be expressed through an ‘active’ clause with a foregrounded agent in subject position \REF{ex:key:1346}: \is{animacy}
Content 1: \gll \textbf{Dɛn} \textbf{bɛ́t}=an na fám. | \gls 3PL bite=3SG.OBJ LOC farm | \glt ?‘She was bitten on the farm.’
Content 2: \gll \textbf{Snék} \textbf{bɛ́t}=an na fám. | \gls snake bite=3SG.OBJ LOC farm | \glt ‘A snake bit her on the farm.’

Knowledge Point: However, impersonal dɛn does not retain its plural reference by default. Sentence \REF{ex:key:1347} was elicited by means of the “caused positions” video clip series of the Language and Cognition Group of the Max Planck Insitute for Psycholinguistics in Nijmegen. In all preceding clips, the agent of a series of actions had been a single individual. Nonetheless, the following sentence was given in response to a still image showing a pot lying upside down on a table:
Content 1: \gll \textbf{Dɛn} \textbf{pút}=an mɔ́t dɔ́n fɔ di tébul. | \gls 3PL put=3SG.OBJ mouth down PREP DEF table | \glt ‘It has been put mouth-down on the table.’

Knowledge Point: In addition to dɛn ‘\textsc{3pl}’, other personal pronouns are also sometimes used with weak reference. Example \REF{ex:key:1350} features the use of wi ‘\textsc{1pl}’ in the idiom which serves as a response to the enquiry ‘how are you?’. Also compare the use of wi in \REF{ex:key:1351}:
Content 1: \gll \textbf{Wi} de pús=an. | \gls 1PL IPFV push=3SG.OBJ | \glt ‘I’m managing.’ [Lit. ‘We’re pushing it.’]
Content 2: \gll Na lɛkɛ \textbf{wí} náw, \textbf{wi} de tɔ́k Panyá, \textbf{wi} go nó sé dís pɔ́sin, na nigeriano. | \gls FOC like 1PL.INDP now 1PL IPFV talk Spanish 1PL POT know QUOT this person FOC Nigerian | \glt ‘It’s like with us now, (if) we spoke Spanish, we would know that this person, is Nigerian.’

Knowledge Point: Likewise, the impersonal backgrounded use of yu ‘\textsc{2sg}’ is common in procedural texts \REF{ex:key:1352}:
Content 1: \gll Dé, ɛ́ni káyn tín na mɔní, \textbf{yu} fít mék ɛ́ni káyn tín \textbf{yu} go sí mɔní. | \gls there every kind thing FOC money 2SG can make every kind thing 2SG POT see money | \glt ‘There, everything is money, you can do anything (and) you’ll earn money.’

Knowledge Point: Finally, the copula and focus marker na ‘\textsc{foc}’ may be used to construct purpose-like clauses \is{purpose clauses}with impersonal reference with an obligation reading in combination with the prepositions fɔ ‘\textsc{prep}’ or to ‘to’ and a subsequent verb without person-marking \REF{ex:key:1353}:
Content 1: \gll \textbf{Na} \textbf{fɔ} tík=an mɔ́. | \gls FOC PREP thicken=3SG.OBJ more | \glt ‘It has to be thickened more.’
